title: 114_s1990
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms such as agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms such as agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. It includes requirements for user authentication, which can involve a password, access device, or unique biometric characteristic. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms and includes requirements for user authentication. The "Federal Computer Security Act" mandates that within 240 days of enactment, each Inspector General of covered agencies must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees detailing logical access standards for Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information. The "Federal Computer Security Act" requires covered agencies to report on their use of logical access controls, including multi-factor authentication, for Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information. If such controls are not used, agencies must provide reasons for their absence and describe data security management practices. The covered agency must report on software inventories and licenses, including security controls for monitoring threats like data loss prevention and digital rights management. If not using such software, reasons for not doing so must be provided. The covered agency must report on software inventories, licenses, and security controls for monitoring threats. The report may be based on audits or evaluations and may include a classified annex. The report submitted under this section must be made available to any Member of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but will be in unclassified form.
